answers.text:
Hi Melissa,
Thanks so much for reaching out to us with this question!  I found these resources that might start you in the right direction for answering your question:
“A public/private partnership composed of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), and the wireless industry” created the Commercial Mobile Alert System, a text-based system that can be used to send geographically-targeted emergency notification text messages.  (http://icma.org/en/icma/newsroom/highlights/Article/101191/Mobile_and_Online_Resources_for_Emergencies)
Williamsburg, VA. found ways to keep in touch with their citizens by working with App-Order, “the leader in smartphone apps for government agencies, through the City’s partnership with the Alliance for Innovation.” (http://icma.org/en/Article/101614/City_of_Williamsburg_VA_Launches_Smartphone_App_for_Citizens)
311 Systems allows for increased dissemination of information during disaster periods, while reducing the load on 911 Emergency Operation Centers. (http://icma.org/en/Page/100225/311CRM_and_Disaster_Response)
Portland, OR. informs its citizens of emergency situation through the Connect and Protect ™ system that it developed in 2003. (http://icma.org/en/Article/100723/Franklin_TN_Unveils_Their_Latest_TechTool)
The ICE: In Case of Emergency app stores valuable information for first responders on the cell phones it is installed on, and can be used to help save lives in your community.
The city of Franklin, TN. decided to keep citizens in the loop by notifying them of crimes using www.crimereports.com, and they managed to reduce robberies by 33% over the program’s first year.  (http://icma.org/en/Article/100723/Franklin_TN_Unveils_Their_Latest_TechTool) 
I hope these resources offer you some new things to consider as you develop your Neighbors Helping Neighbors program.  Please keep us notified about how your project goes, and let us know if we can help you find any more information or resources!!
Aloha, 
James Davidson
Knowledge Network Intern

author: Melissa Zibutis
text:
Hello!
We are looking into a city-wide initiative under our Neighbors Helping Neighbors program where neighbors are connected, either by phone or in person, so that in the event of an emergency, those in need (think Isolated or impaired senior citizens, disabled individuals, etc.) have someone checking in on them. 
I thought some of you might know of similar programs that we could use as a model.
We are just in the infancy phase so any information you have would be great!
title: Emergency Preparedness for Neighbors in Need
